docs.lead_paragraph: A study released yesterday by a national health-care consumers group has found that 650,000 poor children in New York and New Jersey have not been signed up for a supplemental Federal health insurance program that was introduced two years ago. The two states are among the 12 being examined by the group, Families U.S.A., as having the largest numbers of uninsured children. The program, the Children's Health Insurance Program, or CHIP, was introduced in 1997 to provide coverage for uninsured children not eligible for Medicaid.

headline.main: Gaps in Enrollment For Children's Insurance

docs.abstract: Family USA study finds that 650,000 poor children in New York and New Jersey have not been signed up for supplemental Federal health insurance program that was introduced two years ago; Children's Health Insurance Program provides coverage for uninsured children not eligible for Medicaid (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The Clinton Administration wants to give Medicare beneficiaries a list of preferred doctors and hospitals that would agree to discounted rates and reduced fees because, Administration officials say, these health care providers would attract more patients, making up in volume for the lower charges (front page, Oct. 19). Yet a high volume of patients and a high level of medical care are incompatible.

In the late 1980's I signed an agreement to participate with a Medicare program whereby I agreed to accept the lower payments set for me and received a listing in the Medicare handbook as a preferred provider.

docs.lead_paragraph: Tailoring Laughs To the First Lady The question was, what do you do to get psyched to be the M.C. at a birthday tribute for HILLARY RODHAM CLINTON? ROSIE O'DONNELL, who is to play just such a role at just such an event next week, answered with a question: ''You think you need to be psyched to do it?''

byline.original: By JAMES BARRON with William L. Hamilton and Joe Brescia

docs.lead_paragraph: With an overwhelmingly bipartisan vote, the House of Representatives today passed a bill expanding Medicaid and Medicare so that hundreds of thousands of people with disabilities could return to work and keep their health insurance coverage. Under existing law, when disabled people return to work, they often lose Medicaid and Medicare, and without such coverage, they cannot obtain the health care or medical equipment they need to retain their jobs.

headline.main: House Approves Medicare Extension for the Disabled

docs.abstract: House of Representatives, in overwhelmingly bipartisan vote, approves by 412-9 bill expanding Medicaid and Medicare so hundreds of thousands of people with disabilities can return to work and keep health insurance coverage (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ONE rainy morning, I found myself in the back of a taxi in downtown Manhattan. I was tired, having been on call the night before, and feeling a little sorry for myself. I asked the driver -- an immigrant from India, judging from his name -- about his job. He pointed to the tin box in which he was carrying his lunch. ''I work so hard I don't even have time to eat,'' he said. Then he reached under his seat and pulled out a plastic bottle. ''I don't even have time to go to the bathroom.''

headline.main: For Immigrant Drivers, More Than the Taxicab Gets Shaken and Strained

docs.abstract: Dr Sandeep Jauhar article on hard lives of immigrant New York City taxicab drivers; notes drivers work long hours to offset high costs, paying steep health price; photo (Special Section: Cars) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Four northern New Jersey hospitals had their credit ratings lowered by a major bond-rating agency today, a sign that the financial pressures threatening many inner city hospitals have begun to affect affluent communities as well. After reviewing the effects that fee deregulation and insurance industry shake-ups had had on New Jersey health care providers, Standard & Poor's announced that it was downgrading bonds for Rahway Hospital in Union County and three Bergen County hospitals: Englewood Hospital and Medical Center, Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood and Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck.

headline.main: Credit Ratings Are Lowered At 4 Hospitals In New Jersey

docs.abstract: Standard & Poor's lowers credit ratings of Rahway Hospital, Englewood Hospital and Medical Center, Pascack Valley Hospital and Holy Name Hospital in northern New Jersey, sign that financial pressures threatening many inner city hospitals have begun to affect affluent communities as well (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Unhappy that managed care has cut into psychologists' income and autonomy, the New York State Psychological Association and its 3,200 members agreed this month to join the American Federation of Teachers -- the first time a group of American psychologists has affiliated with a union. Officials in the psychologists' association, mostly therapists with doctoral degrees in psychology, said they were affiliating with the A.F.T. largely because the powerful teachers' union would have more clout in lobbying for legislation, in Albany and in Washington, that would force managed care organizations to provide better mental health coverage.

headline.main: New York Psychologists Forming Alliance With a Teachers' Union

docs.abstract: New York State Psychological Association and its 3,200 members, unhappy that managed care has cut into psychologists' income and autonomy, are joining American Federation of Teachers, first affiliation by American psychologists group with union; association officials say union's lobbying clout will force managed care organizations to provide better mental health coverage; union will not be able to bargain collectively for psychologists since 80 percent of them are in private practice; psychologists in other states study NY move as possible model; photo (M)

docs.section_name: Front Page; Health; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: More and more managed care companies in the metropolitan area are refusing to pay for one or more days of patient hospital stays as a way to increase their own profits, hospital administrators say. The Greater New York Hospital Association, a trade group representing area hospitals, has asked the State Attorney General's office to look into the practice, known in the industry as a ''day carve-out.''

headline.main: Length of Stay Is a Target For H.M.O.'s
